pullRequest.body:
Add pdf, CDF and measure of Gamma distribution.
Add proof that this is indeed a probability distribution. Add proofs that relate the various definitions.

TODO: Refactor Probability/Distributions/Exponential.lean using calls to
  the results in this file.


---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
> I've left a bunch of comments. Most of these are just code-style fixes and "golf". The only comment of substance is that I think `pow_exp_integral_Ioi` should be proved in more generality (allowing complex exponents and deducing the real case from that) and moved to a different file.

Thank you, I'll take a good look tomorrow! Regarding some style comments: I took everything from Probability/Distributions/Exponential.lean and tried to stick as closely to that as possible; I should've probably double-checked style, I'll do that tomorrow!

@collares, @JADekker What's going on here? I was in the middle of reviewing this branch, as specifically requested by Josha, and suddenly it's all been changed with a force-push, destroying an hour's work I just spent carefully streamlining the proofs...

I'm very sorry, I was not aware that that would happen. Somehow I bogged up my git and asked for help from @collares to set back my branch; I wasn't aware of these consequences... Is there some way to fix this? Your version is the most up-to-date version, so I'm more than happy if you use that one and make a new PR with it/overwrite the current one entirely, if that is possible!

Don't worry; I manually copy-pasted the changes from my local git branch to somewhere else, downloaded the new git branch, and I'm now back on track. BTW, judging from the latest comments on zulip, it looks like I gave you misleading advice about instance parameters – sorry for that!
No worries! I'm fighting with git on another branch right now, I'll make sure I don't touch this one!

I've pushed a commit which shortens the proofs in `Gamma/Basic.lean` a good deal, and also makes them quicker to compile (since there are fewer repetitions of heavyweight tactics like `simp` and `norm_cast`). I'll look at the other file next.
Thank you for all the fixes, I'll try to be more critical of spelling and grammar in the future as well! I forgot about the batch apply, thank you for reminding me!

@loefflerd would you like me to start refactoring Probability/Distributions/Exponential.lean and tag that along to this PR, or wait until this PR has merged? 

I think I'd also like to add the chi-squared distribution as a special case of the Gamma distribution, as it opens up the way for things like t-distributions; if there is no need for that, I'm happy to wait though!

I did some golfing on `lintegral_gammaPdf_eq_one`. This means `lintegral_eq_lintegral_Ici_add_Iio` is no longer required in this file, so I moved it back to its original home (temporarily; we can get rid of it entirely once that file gets refactored).

I'd advise waiting for a little while (until this gets merged) until you start work on the next stage. Since I am not a maintainer myself, somebody else will have to give the final OK to this, and they might ask for yet more changes; and it's always a pain to forward-port changes between multiple PR's in a series.

OK, this looks good to me now!

I suggest posting on the zulip "PR reviews" queue, asking for a maintainer to make the final merge decision.
I’ll wait until it builds and then post it there! Thank you! Feel free to add yourself to the copyright statement of course, if you like!

:v: JADekker can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7422209299/job/20197054544)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7422209299/job/20197054040)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7422209299/job/20197054260)

Here are some comment. I've tried to fix the spelling / grammar errors in the docstrings for you, since they aren't your fault. (Just in case you aren't aware: you can apply all the suggestions I've made as a batch, by going to the "Files changed" view – that hopefully makes dealing with pedantic reviewers slightly less tedious :smile:)

LGTM, thanks!
Here are 3 very minor comments. You can merge yourself after resolving them.

bors d+

I've left a bunch of comments. Most of these are just code-style fixes and "golf". The only comment of substance is that I think `pow_exp_integral_Ioi` should be proved in more generality (allowing complex exponents and deducing the real case from that) and moved to a different file.

Here are some comment. I've tried to fix the spelling / grammar errors in the docstrings for you, since they aren't your fault. (Just in case you aren't aware: you can apply all the suggestions I've made as a batch, by going to the "Files changed" view – that hopefully makes dealing with pedantic reviewers slightly less tedious :smile:)

LGTM, thanks!
Here are 3 very minor comments. You can merge yourself after resolving them.

bors d+

```suggestion
open scoped ENNReal NNReal
```

(you open it unscoped anyway so this is a no-op)
... on what?
Is your native language German, by any chance? It's not a big deal, but generally we don't capitalise nouns in English (except personal names) and hyphens are used much less.
no, just a shameless copy-paste from Probability/Distributions/Exponential...

Golfs down to
```suggestion
lemma measurable_gammaPdfReal (a r : ℝ) : Measurable (gammaPdfReal a r) := 
  Measurable.ite measurableSet_Ici (((measurable_id'.pow_const _).const_mul _).mul 
    (measurable_id'.const_mul _).neg.exp) measurable_const
```
Is this really needed?
It is a one-liner, so we can just as well remove it indeed!
`ha` and `hr` should be explicit arguments here

```suggestion
      · intro x (hx : 0 < x)
        simp_rw [mul_eq_mul_right_iff, mul_rpow hr.le hx.le, ← mul_assoc, ← mul_rpow hri.le hr.le, 
          mul_comm (1 / r), mul_div, mul_one, div_self hr.ne', one_rpow, one_mul, true_or]
```

```suggestion
  if 0 ≤ x then r ^ a / (Gamma a) * x ^ (a - 1) * exp (-(r * x)) else 0
```
The `↑` is a coercion between types, but everything here has type `Real`, so you don't need this. 

Please also put spaces around binary operators (that's the usual mathlib style), here and elsewhere. 

Since namespace `Real` is already open (and `Complex` is not), `Gamma` is synonymous with `Real.Gamma`; and also `exp` is `Real.exp`, so you don't need the synonym `rexp` which crops up a few times here.

Ditto in `gammaPdf_eq` and many other places below.

I feel this should be proved as a general lemma about Gamma functions (i.e. not in this file), and it would be nice to have the version for complex `a` also.

Note we also favour `0 < a` over `a > 0` etc.

I'm working on this now, I'm fighting with Lean to get the type coercions working, but other than that I think it should be fine, iirc it doesn't use anything too fancy in the complexes. I'll make a commit with all changes, including this one, when it is done. Do you have a suggestion on where to put it? Close to the definition of the gamma integral?

If you have multiple goals, use indentation. Or, better still, avoid having them in the first place:
```suggestion
      rw [Gamma_eq_integral ha]
```

The nested `have` is kind of clumsy; I'd suggest
```suggestion
    rw [mul_assoc, div_mul_eq_mul_div, ← mul_assoc, mul_div_assoc, 
      div_self (Gamma_pos_of_pos ha).ne', mul_one, div_rpow zero_le_one hr.le, one_rpow, 
      mul_one_div, div_self (rpow_pos_of_pos hr _).ne']
```

```suggestion
  · rw [← restrict_Ioi_eq_restrict_Ici]
    refine ContinuousOn.aestronglyMeasurable ?_ measurableSet_Ioi
    refine ContinuousOn.mul ?_ (Continuous.continuousOn (by continuity))
    exact continuousOn_const.mul (continuousOn_id.rpow_const fun x hx ↦ Or.inl (ne_of_gt hx))```
You can leave out the name for instances (currently lean generates horribly long names for some instances, but the name really doesn't matter)

Currently I need to reference this instance explicitly in my solution to get cdf_eq_to_Real to work (see https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/9408#discussion_r1440711941). What is the preferred way to fix that, so I can remove the name?

It's strange that this inference doesn't happen automatically, but the workings of the type class inference system are a mystery to me. If you genuinely do need to give it a name, then there's no problem with that.
Yes, I am surprised as well, but I don't have a solid background in CS, so I'll leave it be for now.
Use of `;` in mathlib code is discouraged. Try `refine (integral_eq_lintegral_of_nonneg_ae ?_ ?_).symm` and it doesn't create the `rfl` goal anyway
Why use `Fact` here? I'm actually rather surprised that this works at all.

I just took the code from Probability/Distributions/Exponential.lean here, I didn't think too much about it here. It seems that cdf_eq_to_Real cannot infer that `gammaMeasure a r` has IsProbabilityMeasure. I got rid of the Fact's here and made the arguments explicit. To make cdf_eq_to_real happy, I have added a 'have : ...' statement to enforce this inference, but there is probably a better way.

```suggestion
  rw [gammaCdfReal, cdf_eq_toReal, gammaMeasure, withDensity_apply _ measurableSet_Iic]
```

Looks great, thanks for adding this! Can you maybe move it to `SpecialFunctions.Gamma.Basic` or somewhere like that (somewhere shortly after the definition of `Complex.Gamma`)?

I would also suggest a different name, maybe `integral_cpow_mul_exp_neg_mul_Ioi`, for this lemma; and similarly the real version should be `integral_rpow_mul_exp_neg_mul_Ioi`. (Generally we distinguish between different kinds of exponentiation depending on the type of the exponent, so `pow` means Nat exponent, and other kinds of powers are `zpow, rpow, cpow`.)

How painful would it be to deduce the real-variable version (the current `pow_exp_integral_Ioi`) from the complex version, rather than giving a separate proof as currently?

Thank you, I'll incorporate all this and make a new commit right away. Deducing should be easy, but I wanted to wait until the location was determined, so I wouldn't have to keep changing imports in Distributions/Gamma.
New commit made, all points are now reflected there!
This doesn't seem to refer to any result in this file.

```suggestion
* `gammaCdfReal`: the CDF given by the definition of CDF in `ProbabilityTheory.Cdf` applied to the Gamma measure.
```
Please standardise on one of "PDF" vs "Pdf" vs "pdf" in docstrings (and similarly for CDFs)
Good catch! I'm familiar with 'pdf' and 'CDF', so I'll stick to that convention!

```suggestion
/-- the Gamma PDF is positive for all positive reals -/
```

```suggestion
/-- The Gamma PDF is nonnegative -/
```

```suggestion
/-- The PDF of the Gamma distribution, as a function valued in `ℝ≥0∞` -/
```

```suggestion
/-- the Lebesgue integral of the Gamma PDF over nonpositive reals equals 0 -/
```
Doesn't this duplicate the new functionality added to `SpecialFunctions.Gamma.Basic`?

it calls that function, but it is a bit inefficient yes. The idea is that we divide by the constants that appear in the RHS from the function that we added to `SpecialFunctions.Gamma.Basic` are moved to the other side. It is an intermediate result for lintegral_gammaPdf_eq_one, I could try to refactor that proof? 
Also I agree docstring is a bit confusing here, the function doesn't really do what it promises.
Done, I've removed that function and refactored the proof in the most recent commit.

```suggestion
/-- The PDF of the Gamma distribution integrates to 1 -/
```

```suggestion
/-- Measure defined by the Gamma distribution -/
```
I think this should be lowercase `isProbabilityMeasureGamma` (but I'm not 100% sure since I have never understood the logic behind the naming conventions)
I think so too!

```suggestion
/-- CDF of the Gamma distribution -/
```

```suggestion
  · exact (measurable_gammaPdfReal a r).aestronglyMeasurable.restrict
```

```suggestion
  · exact ae_of_all _ fun b ↦ by simp only [Pi.zero_apply, gammaPdfReal_nonneg ha hr]
```
`a` and `r` can be implicitized (and `x` should probably be the last argument)
Will do!

```suggestion
* `gammaCdfReal`: the CDF given by the definition of CDF in `ProbabilityTheory.Cdf` applied to the
  Gamma measure.
```

```suggestion
/-- The pdf of the gamma distribution depending on its scale and rate-/
```

```suggestion
lemma gammaCdfReal_eq_integral {a r : ℝ} (ha : 0 < a) (hr : 0 < r) (x : ℝ) :
```

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat : Add Gamma distribution
